story:
We want to reach abandoned and impoverished children, put a smile on their face, and warm their heart through the gift of art.

My name is  Chris Petrocchi. For the past 20 years I have been a professional artist working on projects both digital and traditional in visual development for games and film. But Late in 2013 I suffered significant loss of sight in my left eye due to a condition called NAION or non arthritic ischemic neuropathy. Over the course of about 4 weeks the damage was done. My right eye worked fine, but my left eye was useless for drawing. During that very dark period I thought my career was over. I felt as if I would never be able to draw again, at least not like I used to. BUT FROM THIS CAME SOMETHING POSITIVE, AND I WANT TO SHARE IT WITH YOU.

It was around that time I found out about Ben Schumaker. He had been going to different orphanages and taking pictures of the kids faces. He would bring the pictures home to the states and have art students draw and paint portraits of these kids and then deliver the portraits back to the kids as keepsakes. 

I instantly fell in love with the idea and felt it was a chance for me to help others through art and in spite my eye loss. I was determined to have a try. 

In 2014 I took a trip to China to visit an orphanage. This is the great part: I was able to get photos of the kids and bring them back to the states and had my art students paint their portraits. So I am half way there to completing this outreach project! My site documenting the trip can be seen here: http://iseeu.squarespace.com

ALL I NEED TO DO IS TAKE THE PORTRAITS BACK TO THE KIDS IN CHINA!

I am so excited and passionate about this, and I believe it can really make a difference in their lives. The kids don't have much nor do they have any photos of themselves or a good sense of their value. 

These portraits are well made and can last for years. As such they are something that a child can reflect on and realize that someone thought about them and cared enough to paint their picture. On the back of each painting is a picture of the artist and a personal note from the artist about their life along with an encouraging word for the child. 

This is a fantastic opportunity to touch the lives of children who are in tough circumstances and for me personally, to turn the loss I sustained into something really good and positive. I love that idea. I want to replicate this process over and over and touch the lives of many more kids out there in the world who don't have families. This is huge. This is my beginning.

What We Need & What You Get

  • To make this happen I need $3500.00 to return back to China and deliver the portraits. That would complete the first cycle. Please keep in mind that once I arrive there is one inland flight and a road trip necessary to reach the orphanage in Yunnan province. While I am there I plan to visit another orphanage and do the process all over again. This would require another $3500.00. So in total I am looking for $7500.00. This would go towards plane tickets there and back and accommodations.
  • If we don't  reach our goal we will use the money raised to go forward with delivering the artwork to the kids this summer.

  • The Impact
  • This outreach will "feed" the children we are able to reach for a long time in the sense that as they grow, they can refer back to their portrait and start to ask questions like: who painted my portrait? why would anyone want to paint me? am I that beautiful? They may also have a sense of gratitude that someone did think about them and did take the time to paint their portrait and write them a personal note.
  • So far we have successfully visited one orphanage in China and have completed all the portraits to send back to the kids there.

Risks & Challenges

        It's not easy to gain access to many orphanages. Administrators are suspicious         of foreigners coming there and taking photos because of social media and the             possibility that photos can be spread all over the internet these days. The                     biggest challenge we face is getting people familiar with what it is we are doing           and building trust by respecting the guidelines and limitations they require us             to follow.
  • We are able to communicate directly in Chinese with the officials and administrators.
  • We plan to contact orphanages ahead of time to cultivate a relationship with them and begin a dialogue about the process. I have published a website that shows in detail what it is we do so that people quickly "get it".
story_txt:
We want to reach abandoned and impoverished children, put a smile on their face, and warm their heart through the gift of art.
My name is  Chris Petrocchi. For the past 20 years I have been a professional artist working on projects both digital and traditional in visual development for games and film. But Late in 2013 I suffered significant loss of sight in my left eye due to a condition called NAION or non arthritic ischemic neuropathy. Over the course of about 4 weeks the damage was done. My right eye worked fine, but my left eye was useless for drawing. During that very dark period I thought my career was over. I felt as if I would never be able to draw again, at least not like I used to. BUT FROM THIS CAME SOMETHING POSITIVE, AND I WANT TO SHARE IT WITH YOU.


It was around that time I found out about Ben Schumaker. He had been going to different orphanages and taking pictures of the kids faces. He would bring the pictures home to the states and have art students draw and paint portraits of these kids and then deliver the portraits back to the kids as keepsakes. 


I instantly fell in love with the idea and felt it was a chance for me to help others through art and in spite my eye loss. I was determined to have a try. 
In 2014 I took a trip to China to visit an orphanage. This is the great part: I was able to get photos of the kids and bring them back to the states and had my art students paint their portraits. So I am half way there to completing this outreach project! My site documenting the trip can be seen here: http://iseeu.squarespace.com
ALL I NEED TO DO IS TAKE THE PORTRAITS BACK TO THE KIDS IN CHINA!
I am so excited and passionate about this, and I believe it can really make a difference in their lives. The kids don't have much nor do they have any photos of themselves or a good sense of their value. 
These portraits are well made and can last for years. As such they are something that a child can reflect on and realize that someone thought about them and cared enough to paint their picture. On the back of each painting is a picture of the artist and a personal note from the artist about their life along with an encouraging word for the child. 
This is a fantastic opportunity to touch the lives of children who are in tough circumstances and for me personally, to turn the loss I sustained into something really good and positive. I love that idea. I want to replicate this process over and over and touch the lives of many more kids out there in the world who don't have families. This is huge. This is my beginning.
What We Need & What You Get
  To make this happen I need $3500.00 to return back to China and deliver the portraits. That would complete the first cycle. Please keep in mind that once I arrive there is one inland flight and a road trip necessary to reach the orphanage in Yunnan province. While I am there I plan to visit another orphanage and do the process all over again. This would require another $3500.00. So in total I am looking for $7500.00. This would go towards plane tickets there and back and accommodations. If we don't  reach our goal we will use the money raised to go forward with delivering the artwork to the kids this summer.


The Impact
  This outreach will "feed" the children we are able to reach for a long time in the sense that as they grow, they can refer back to their portrait and start to ask questions like: who painted my portrait? why would anyone want to paint me? am I that beautiful? They may also have a sense of gratitude that someone did think about them and did take the time to paint their portrait and write them a personal note. So far we have successfully visited one orphanage in China and have completed all the portraits to send back to the kids there.    Risks & Challenges
        It's not easy to gain access to many orphanages. Administrators are suspicious         of foreigners coming there and taking photos because of social media and the             possibility that photos can be spread all over the internet these days. The                     biggest challenge we face is getting people familiar with what it is we are doing           and building trust by respecting the guidelines and limitations they require us             to follow.

We are able to communicate directly in Chinese with the officials and administrators. We plan to contact orphanages ahead of time to cultivate a relationship with them and begin a dialogue about the process. I have published a website that shows in detail what it is we do so that people quickly "get it".

story:
About us...

We are all Virginia State winners in our Future Business Leaders of America organization and students in Virginia Beach.  We have been in a program the past 2 years to teach us about Information Technology and Cyber Security skills.

We are eligible to compete at a National level in Chicago IL this June, but our Federal funding was abruptly stopped and our division has no local funds to support our continued education and progress.

Your contribution will help us improve our knowledge and abilities in the areas of:

  • Cyber Security (Information Assurance)
  • Networking Design
  • Databases
  • Project Management
  • Teamwork & Leadership
  • Business Planning and Project Development
Your contributions will help us pay for the airfare, hotel and conference registration fees.  We will be able to take part in educational workshops as well as competing against students from around the country.  This will allow us to improve our IT and Business skills and validate our education.

The Costs

  • Registration:  105 pp
  • Hotel:  900 for a room of 4 individuals
  • Airfare - approx 350-400pp. 
Any money raised will go to above costs.  Any additional funds will help us with food expenses, or we will reserve for next year's competitors at our school

The Impact

The need for trained Cyber Security individuals is strong.  Our ability to compete here will allow us to grow and improve so we can pursue careers in these fields and be productive members of society.

Risks & Challenges

We are trying to do local fundraisers, but our time is limited with deadlines to register and obtain affordable airfare.  We just won at the State Level last week so we had limited time to prepare for this opportunity.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please donate whatever you can, ask your friends, neighbors, co-workers and businesses to help support us!  We are 6 high school students with great promise and potential, we just need solid community support!
  • Use your social media and the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word!

We thank you so much for your support!

story:
"The extremists were and they are afraid of books and pens. The power of education frightens them. They are afraid of women. The power of the voice of women frightens them." - Malala Yousafzai

NOW that girls in rural Afghanistan can once again attend school after being forbidden by the Taliban for so many years they need our HELP! 

I need your help getting pens to these young women yearning to make the most out of their education.  By working with TAPS, pens and supplies will be distributed to the schoolgirls.

My name is Gavrielle and I began this campaign earlier this year while attending high school at Sacred Heart Cathedral in San Francisco. Now I am in college and realize even more how important it is to help these girls with their education and dreams.

After watching the news story below and seeing that Zahra could not take notes in school because she could not afford to buy a pen I felt a wave of emotions ranging from amazement and disbelief to sadness and anger.

     


I was also struck by how fortunate I am and how something as basic as not having a pen threatens this beautiful, strong and determined 10th grader's dream of attending school and hope of one day becoming a doctor. A pen?

Even more disheartening, is that so many Americans, both men and women, have sacrificed so much in Afghanistan, many even giving their lives so that children like Zahra can even now go to school – and here I see her tears and fears from the lack of a pen. A pen.

Having learned this, I am asking for your help.

My first inclination was to find out how to send my own school supplies to Zahra, but Khazar tells me that showing favoritism to any one student or school is not recommended and could endanger them by causing jealousy and bring unwanted attention. 

I have an idea, but I need your help.

In order to help Zahra, we need to help thousands of Zahras! :)

[ Do you notice anything missing in these photos? ]

My new goal is to now raise enough money so together, WE can provide basic school supplies -- pens, pencils and paper to start…to many schools in rural northern Afghanistan, including Zahra's. If we meet our goal I hope to include spiral notebooks. If we exceed our goal then we can send some whiteboards and markers or chalk boards, with erasers and chalk for their teachers. 

[ There is one -  one pen ]

I found a 10 pack of pens at Safeway for $2.49 -- surely we will buy supplies wholesale and in bulk quantities for much much less. 

                               

Below are some basic costs in Afghanistan according to experts:

$31     –  Paper and pens for an entire class

$63    –  One year education for a student

$90    –  Monthly salary for a teacher

$156   –  Carpets to sit on and water pump for an entire school

$344  –  Carpets to sit on, chalk board, water reservoirs and one teacher                               education kit for one class

$187,000  – One standard school with 6 classrooms 

The reporter, Khazar Fatemi, was also once a student in Afghanistan. She says there are thousands and thousands of children of all ages like Zahra, all eager to learn. They endure substandard conditions and hardships in their attempts to get an education with many classrooms even outside on dirt floors. The more well off students carry a notebook and a pen or pencil to record the teacher’s lessons, but a vast majority of students (especially in rural villages) are so poor they have no supplies and can rely only on memorization.

With advice from Khazar and my dad (he produces for her), we have chosen a non-profit they are familiar with in Washington, DC called TAPS -- the Tragedy Assistance Program for Survivors to be a partner and the recipient of the donations since they can be both tax deductible for you and TAPS is a very reputable, and trustworthy charity with a strong connection and bond with the people of Afghanistan. 

       [A message from Bonnie Carroll, Founder and President of T.A.P.S.]
    


Great Non-Profits

TAPS main mission is to help the survivors in families (husbands, wives, sons, daughters, siblings, parents) whose loved ones gave their lives serving our country in the military, which includes those killed while serving in Afghanistan. 

One small TAPS initiative buys and resells jewelry bracelets made by war widows in Kabul that helps support their livelihoods and allowing them to sending their children to school. http://www.taps.org/afghan/ And a donation PERK for you!

          

Also, by involving TAPS it allows these military families and children survivors to be involved. It helps them knowing that the some of the neediest children and girls now able to attend schools in Afghanistan will have a chance for opportunity. 

It helps promote healing from them knowing that students will have proper school supplies to go along with the opportunity their loved one gave their lives providing to Zahra and others.

I just started college at Lewis and Clark, and am not an aide worker or expert (although I hope to join the Peace Corps after graduation), but I want to do something to help now, I can’t do it alone, but with your help, and the more of us working together, I am sure we can make this happen and have a positive impact on so many young lives.

I am very confident Bonnie, TAPS and our team will work together and find the lowest cost pricing, best delivery, and distribution of any and all supplies to Zahra, her classmates and many more students at other schools.  Please join us?

I am setting an ambitious fundraising goal of $31,000 over 60 days. (one thousand classrooms)

I will work on developing more Perks, but hopefully everyone can expect photos and maybe a Photo Essay with pictures of the school supplies being packaged with care and love by TAPS families and distributed at Afghan schools with video if possible. 

[ The TAPS Good Grief Camps provide support and comfort for children of all ages facing the loss of a loved one in military service. ]

The thought of these children and teens being able to send pens and supplies to help the Zahras and to honor their loved one makes me tear up.

My personal wish is for a picture or video of Zahra smiling while holding lots of colorful pens.

Also, I will personally send you a thank you note - the old fashioned kind, in the mail, with a stamp, handwritten, in pen. :)

If we don't reach our entire goal, then what funds we raise will still go to buy supplies whether several hundred, a few thousand or tens of thousands of pens.

I am donating $100 (earned from my part-time job).

Any amount you can give is appreciated. 

You can even support us by just sharing positive thoughts, words of encouragement and this link. 

Thank you so much for your consideration. 

Peace and Love, 

      Gavrielle


              

P.S. How awesome are Khazar and Bonnie? What amazing role models for me, Zahra and girls everywhere!

story:
The Velma-Alma Elementary PTO are offering our Comet family (past or present) the opportunity to help with fundraising for this exciting and worthwhile project by having your name or business permanently memorialized on our beloved Comet Campus.  We have been working diligently raising funds to provide a new and much needed quality playground for our elementary students to enjoy for decades to come. There are several giving options listed below available for purchase by selecting whichever "perk" you desire or you are able to make a contribution for any amount you choose.  

PURCHASE A PICKET $50-$100

Surrounding the new playground will be a picket fence (installed this summer break) engraved with the names of families, students, and businesses that were a part of the effort to bring this wonderful new feature to our school campus. “Pickets” are being sold on a first come, first serve basis and are offered at two different price points. Pickets for individuals are $50 with examples including (but not limited to) individual names, family names, students, alumni, pickets “in memory” of a loved one, and former/current faculty, staff and administration.  Pickets for businesses and organizations are $100 with examples being any business name, club, organization, former comet classes, etc.  Some businesses may choose to purchase multiple pickets with each one displayed on different areas of the fence to ensure maximum visibility.  Pickets are also a great gift idea for that person who is so hard to buy for, and we can provide a certificate verifying the donation in their name. Since the new fence will be constructed with composite materials, your donation will be memorialized on our Comet Campus for decades to come!

BECOME A DONOR $250-$5,000

We are offering 5 different sponsorship levels for our generous donors.  Each donor will receive one picket with prominent placement on the fence and also their name or business forever memorialized on our special “Donor Wall” located inside the playground area.  The Donor Wall will display all donors categorized by their sponsorship level which are Bronze-$250, Silver-$500, Gold-$1,000, Platinum-$2,500, and Playground Benefactor- $5,000 or more.

SPONSOR A PLAYGROUND COMPONENT $1,000-$35,000

When you sponsor a playground component, an engraved plaque will be permanently placed on or near that piece of equipment with an inscription of your choice (examples include  an individual name, family, in memory of a loved one, any business, organization, or any other idea you may have).  Photos of the components (ranging in price from $1,000-$35,000) are available on the gallery tab of this fundraiser.  Playground components are available on a first come, first serve basis so we ask that you please contact us to verify the availability of the desired component and instructions on how to purchase.

CONTACT US

Call or text Heather Williams @ 580-606-2103 or Chanda Wright @ 580-467-7256
Email velmaalmapto@yahoo.com
Facebook Page "Velma-Alma Elementary PTO"

story:
Welcome to Hastings' New Independent Art School www.niash.org

(Charity status pending)

This is an ambitious project, set up by local Hastings and London based artists. The project aims to have a one-year Post Graduate course up and running by October 2016.

NIASH

New Independent Art School Hastings is an artist led initiative currently at the embryonic stage of development. The project came about through a series of conversations that led to the writing of a post graduate course, and through necessity has led to the expansion of the initiative into a collection of arts and humanities focused short courses, projects, and programmes.

In the spirit of our original vision regarding deficits in current art establishment practice, and inspired by the focus of the post graduate course (still in its developmental stages) the school's learning programme has been developed with the social, the collective, and the critical in mind.

In line with this egalitarian spirit, we've invited practicing artists to write courses informed by their own current disciplines; asking them to look at their individual practices as a starting point. They have been given the freedom to write courses that push the boundaries of the conventional, and have been encouraged to celebrate and explore what is unique within their own practice and research. Collaboration, inter disciplinary, collectivity and inclusivity are at the heart of the short course programme.

One-Year Post Graduate Course

Critical Art Practice & Society is a brand new radical fine art course, located 3 minutes from the seafront in Hastings at the heart of the south east coast contemporary art scene. Our ethos proceeds from an avant-gardist conception of art as political, formally experimental, and socially positioned.

The programme is structured as a series of seven intensive modules over the course of one year.

Students will take a proactive role as producers of artworks, events and writings. The course includes activities such as the organization of exhibitions, broadcasts and talks; research into questions of function, funding and methodology; and the writing of a manifesto. 

Practice and theory are not separated on this course but are understood within a unified approach to critical teaching, thinking and production. Discussions, group readings and screenings will accompany all modules. There is an emphasis on collaboration understood not in a banal sense of participation but in the strongest critical, political and social sense as what we call ‘conspirative’: from ‘con’ (together) + ‘spirare’ (breath).

Hastings' distinctive creative spirit offers students on this course unique opportunities for public and collaborative art projects.

Short Course

Our short course programme starts in September 2015 and has been written by established Artists living and working in Hastings. The subjects will range from sound art to political theory, performance to experimental drawing, and creative writing to sculpture as process.

The programme's timetable has been designed to fit with different domestic circumstances to make learning more accessible to those who may have barriers that restrict their free time, such as work, family, and geographical distance. 

We will be running 10 week evening classes during term time, three hours per session, for those who have daytime commitments, as well as 20 hour intensive week long courses running within school hours for parents and carers, and 20 hour weekend courses that will span five weeks of four hour sessions.

We have endeavoured to keep our courses affordable in order to make the programmed accessible to all.

Summer School

We also have a very exciting summer school programme starting in June with intensive one-week courses in a plethora of intriguing and inspiring subjects. We have offered these courses at a discounted price to our Indiegogo supporters in our list of 'perks'.

Open source

We will be documenting and archiving all the work that happens within and around the school. With plans for future works, shows, films, and publications to be produced. The archive will be accessible to the public. Students, researchers, and artists working within the school will be encouraged to contribute as well as utilize this information to help inform the future development of our arts/educational programme.

The school aims to be self sustaining by October 2016 and by 2017 we aim to be in a position to invest any surplus in projects outside the school, essentially creating a new funding pot for artists and art organizations to access for projects external to the school itself.

Location

NIASH is currently based at Rock House (previously Rothermere House) at 49-51 Cambridge Road, Hastings.

Owned by White Rock Neighbourhood Ventures (WRNV), Rock House is an ambitious mixed-use project intended to breathe new life into an underused building, creating a mixed living/working/club space in the heart of Hastings Town Centre.

The project is based on the principals of co-housing, where sharing resources and participation in the community - both within the building and in the wider White Rock area of Hastings - is key.

Local people will have the opportunity to access affordable living and working space in this creative, community-centered building. WRNV also aims to make the most of an unusual (and currently unloved) alleyway space. 

White Rock Neighbourhood Ventures Ltd is a joint venture between three complementary social enterprise organisations. These are: 

•  Meanwhile Space CIC 

•  Jericho Road Solutions

The White Rock Trust - providing leadership, investment, and development guidelines.

WRNV began the project by taking ownership of Rock House in summer 2014, and is in the process of fully redeveloping the building. The space will comprise of 425 square meters of living space and 804 square meters of workspace over 9 floors.

More information can be found at www.niash.org 

Outreach

From the outset, NIASH has planned to run programmes external to the school; working to bring art practice and education to areas of the town that have not been well served by the cultural and creative sectors in the past.

Hastings has a rich cultural heritage, with an established and growing community of artists, craftists, designers, filmmakers and musicians. This vibrant and pro-active community has grown organically - with its roots firmly planted within the unique autonomous, 'independent' and politically dissenting identity Hastings thankfully refuses to let go of. 

The smugglers, the Tubman, the pirates, the witches, the chimney sweeps, the fisherman, and the bonfire boys are all a part of our fiercely anti-establishment history and have left their indelible mark on the town, much of which can still be seen today.

The areas of our town that have - against all odds - maintained their historic identities serve as a brilliant backdrop for the creative communities that have developed here over the decades. But the town has sprawled out beyond these wards, and has thus far failed to extend this intoxicating spirit to its outer limits.

The forgotten wards such as Ore and Hollington have their own identities and communities, with some incredible projects already being established within them. NIASH aims to create projects and programmes designed to draw these forgotten wards into the fold, celebrating their burgeoning creative identities and building inclusive networks through collective creative experiences.

Everyone involved in the project is currently working voluntarily to create the course, exhibition, and residency programmes.

What we don't currently have is funding to help us buy equipment needed to run projects and courses and furnish the space. We need audio equipment, cameras, computers and software for sound based, graphics, animation and film courses and projects. We need drawing boards and drawing, collage and painting materials. We also need basic furniture such as built in cupboards, chairs, desks and sound dampening equipment. As we transform the space we will also need paint and other decorating materials. We hope to raise enough here to be able to use that money as a match fund enabling us to equip the school properly.
story_txt:
Welcome to
Hastings' New Independent Art School www.niash.org
(Charity
status pending)
This is an
ambitious project, set up by local Hastings and London based artists. The
project aims to have a one-year Post Graduate course up and running by October
2016.
NIASH
New
Independent Art School Hastings is an artist led initiative currently at the
embryonic stage of development. The project came about through a series of
conversations that led to the writing of a post graduate course, and through
necessity has led to the expansion of the initiative into a collection of arts
and humanities focused short courses, projects, and programmes.
In the spirit
of our original vision regarding deficits in current art establishment
practice, and inspired by the focus of the post graduate course (still in its
developmental stages) the school's learning programme has been developed with
the social, the collective, and the critical in mind.
In line with
this egalitarian spirit, we've invited practicing artists to write courses
informed by their own current disciplines; asking them to look at their
individual practices as a starting point. They have been given the freedom to
write courses that push the boundaries of the conventional, and have been
encouraged to celebrate and explore what is unique within their own practice
and research. Collaboration, inter disciplinary, collectivity and inclusivity
are at the heart of the short course programme.
One-Year Post
Graduate Course
Critical Art
Practice & Society is a brand new radical fine art course, located 3
minutes from the seafront in Hastings at the heart of the south east coast
contemporary art scene. Our ethos proceeds from an avant-gardist conception of
art as political, formally experimental, and socially positioned.
The programme
is structured as a series of seven intensive modules over the course of one
year.
Students will
take a proactive role as producers of artworks, events and writings. The course
includes activities such as the organization of exhibitions, broadcasts and
talks; research into questions of function, funding and methodology; and the
writing of a manifesto. 
Practice and
theory are not separated on this course but are understood within a unified
approach to critical teaching, thinking and production. Discussions, group
readings and screenings will accompany all modules. There is an emphasis on
collaboration understood not in a banal sense of participation but in the
strongest critical, political and social sense as what we call ‘conspirative’:
from ‘con’ (together) + ‘spirare’ (breath).
Hastings'
distinctive creative spirit offers students on this course unique opportunities
for public and collaborative art projects.
Short Course
Our short
course programme starts in September 2015 and has been written by
established Artists living and working in Hastings. The subjects will range
from sound art to political theory, performance to experimental drawing, and
creative writing to sculpture as process.
The
programme's timetable has been designed to fit with different domestic
circumstances to make learning more accessible to those who may have barriers
that restrict their free time, such as work, family, and geographical
distance. 
We will be
running 10 week evening classes during term time, three hours per session, for
those who have daytime commitments, as well as 20 hour intensive week long
courses running within school hours for parents and carers, and 20 hour weekend
courses that will span five weeks of four hour sessions.
We have
endeavoured to keep our courses affordable in order to make the programmed
accessible to all.
Summer School
We also have
a very exciting summer school programme starting in June with intensive one-week
courses in a plethora of intriguing and inspiring subjects. We have offered
these courses at a discounted price to our Indiegogo supporters in our list of
'perks'.
Open source
We will be
documenting and archiving all the work that happens within and around the
school. With plans for future works, shows, films, and publications to be
produced. The archive will be accessible to the public. Students, researchers,
and artists working within the school will be encouraged to contribute as well
as utilize this information to help inform the future development of our
arts/educational programme.
The school
aims to be self sustaining by October 2016 and by 2017 we aim to be in a
position to invest any surplus in projects outside the school, essentially
creating a new funding pot for artists and art organizations to access for
projects external to the school itself.
Location
NIASH is
currently based at Rock House (previously Rothermere House) at 49-51 Cambridge
Road, Hastings.
Owned by
White Rock Neighbourhood Ventures (WRNV), Rock House is an ambitious mixed-use
project intended to breathe new life into an underused building, creating a
mixed living/working/club space in the heart of Hastings Town Centre.
The project
is based on the principals of co-housing, where sharing resources and
participation in the community - both within the building and in the wider
White Rock area of Hastings - is key.
Local people
will have the opportunity to access affordable living and working space in this
creative, community-centered building. WRNV also aims to make the most of an
unusual (and currently unloved) alleyway space. 
White Rock
Neighbourhood Ventures Ltd is a joint venture between three complementary
social enterprise organisations. These are: 
• 
Meanwhile Space CIC 
• 
Jericho Road Solutions
The White
Rock Trust - providing leadership, investment, and development guidelines.
WRNV began
the project by taking ownership of Rock House in summer 2014, and is in the
process of fully redeveloping the building. The space will comprise of 425
square meters of living space and 804 square meters of workspace over 9 floors.
More
information can be found at www.niash.org 
Outreach
From the
outset, NIASH has planned to run programmes external to the school; working to bring art
practice and education to areas of the town that have not been well served by
the cultural and creative sectors in the past.
Hastings has
a rich cultural heritage, with an established and growing community of artists,

fisherman, and the bonfire boys are all a part of our fiercely

of which can still be seen today.

story:
“We are not doing this to make them musicians but to give them their childhood back.” Tamer Nafar, Palestinian Hip Hop Artist.

Summary of Project:

Hip hop was an art form that had arisen out of the South Bronx of New York City during the 70s. It is a perfect example of how creative art forms arise out of times of turmoil. The 1970s was a time when New York City was characterized with despair and hopelessness, and neighborhoods like the South Bronx felt it the most. Out of this art form came artists with a great deal of social consciousness, such as KRS-One and Boogie Down Productions, which was then followed by groups such as Public Enemy whose lyrics all had political commentary, and these artist were not afraid of controversy, as they expressed feelings of frustration felt by African-Americans and other minority communities throughout the United States. 

Little did many of these artists realize was that their music would have an impact on communities who felt oppressed and disconnected all over the world, from the Middle Eastern and South Asian communities of Europe to the Middle East itself to many different parts of Africa. Even the famous Korean rapper, Psy, was actually making a satirical video, when he created the famous song and video, Gangnam Style. Many of Psy’s music have a great deal of social and political commentary about Korean society and the rest of the world.

Last year I had created a curriculum called Hip Hop as a Vehicle for Social Change. I came across an article about Palestinian Hip Hop. I have read about Middle Eastern hip hop artists, as well as European hip hop artists of Middle Eastern and South Asian descent, but this article helped give me a much better insight of the hip hop scene in the Middle East. I could not help but draw the parallels between how hip hop thrived in Palestine and how it first originated in the South Bronx during the 1970s, which is how I created this curriculum.

As someone who grew up on hip hop, too, I have seen the music evolve from an art form in the South Bronx to a completely global movement. No matter what part of the world, the underlying theme is always the same. It serves as a voice for youth who feel alienated and disenfranchised, and through this art form it has had the capability to transform the social environment, empowering youth in a way that they never thought they could. It has also influenced presidential elections, which I highlight in the piece, while also serving as the soundtrack for Arab Spring.

While hip hop is often portrayed negatively in the media and has become very commercialized in much of the world, there are still pockets of the hip hop community that have maintained the authenticity of the art form and have even used it as a powerful tool to affect social change, and this is what my curriculum is about. I created this curriculum for high school teachers and college professors. The course can be taught in either a social studies class, especially in a Civics class, as well as an English class. The Website serves as blueprint for educators who can tailor it to their own classroom.

This year I was approved to present this curriculum at the IEARN 2015 Conference. which is taking place in Brasilia. IEARN is a non-governmental organization that I have been a member of for almost 15 years. The organization seeks to unite students and educators all over the world through project-based, collaborative learning, utilizing the Internet as the means for this to happen, and now I have the opportunity to present this workshop to my fellow members, including many educators from the Middle East. The host nation this year is also an ideal location because the nation of Brazil has also served as another hub for socially conscious, progressive hip hop. Please find a breakdown of the budget below:

Budget:

Round Trip Flight- $1,200.00

Conference Fee(Includes Meals) and Lodging: $660,00

Additional Taxes and Fees; $40.00

Total: $1,900*

*I just recently heard from IEARN Brazil that they have found a much more affordable housing option for Conference participants, which is right near the actual conference space. This option will cover room, board and conference registratrion fees. This is a huge break for me, as it cuts the cost for this trip substantially, which is discussed in the Updates, making my goal much closer within reach. This is the reason for the discrepancy, in case you were wondering. Now, I only have to raise $1,900, instead of the original $2,400 that I had originally set as a goal.

Impact:
"This project curriculum is an effective way to reach out to youth who feel marginalized and teach them how to use their voice to create change by awakening the societal consciousness," said Renee Noelle Day, a high school teacher at the Riverside Unified School District in Southern California. Ms. Day is also a member of IEARN and is always interested in finding new and interesting curriculum that she can use to better reach out to her students. She was very impressed, when she saw this curriculum.

The organization IEARN has served as a powerful platform to unite students and educators from all over the world. My life literally changed so much, when I attended my first IEARN conference in Capetown in 2001, that I attended two more after. I want to be able to do the same for other educators. A workshop such as this fits very well with the mission of IEARN, which is why they approved me to present it. This curriculum can serve as a powerful tool to help young people understand that their voices actually do count and that they have more in common with their peers all over the world than they think. 

As an educator and community organizer for 18 years, I have a proven track record of developing curriuculum, creating programs that involve civic engagement, and providing professional development to other educators. I am also a huge fan of hip hop: the graffiti. I remember, when I first listened to political hip hop artists, such a KRS-1, Public Enemy and Paris. I lamented, when I saw hip hop artists here in the United States stray away from this kind of socially conscious hip hop but was ecstatic to find out that there was a new generation of hip hop artists overseas who were continuing to this type of hip hop. Artists like Lowkey, Abdallah, Tamer Nafar, and Okinawan rapper Akiko Urasaki have carried that torch and are not afraid to push the envelope because that is what music is supposed to do: transform societies.  I truly believe that this curriculum can be a very useful tool for other educators to better reach out to many of their students, particularly the ones who feel extremely marginalized, and now I have an opportunity to reach out to a wider audience. 

The curriculum also helps young people realize that they have more in common than they realize. The recent protests in Ferguson, Missouri regarding the shooting of Michael Brown was a perfect example. Young people in the West Bank and the Gaza strip were tweeting information to the protester in Ferguson about how to avoid tear gas.  The curriculum can bridge the academic and  real world so that what is actually discussed in academia is actually implemented in the real world and in real time. 

Furthermore, we now live in an age where there is too much emphasis in the education community on standardized testing. Educators all throughout the United States are inundated with policy about meeting the Common Core standards to the point that some schools practically teach to a test. Parents and their children are constantly bombarded with information about high stakes testing. A curriculum such as this allows educators to not only teach material that will appeal to their students, but will also allow them to expand their mind and understand why education is so important in their lives. After all, the mission of giving someone an education is not only to provide them knowledge that allows them to function as a productive citizen, but it also teaches them how to think. The curriculum can also help students meet Common Core student because it does teach students how to think critically while also demonstrating how to illustrate a point and make an argument, all part of the goals and objectives of the Common Core.

Unfortunately, I am given a very short time window. I have to let the conference organizers know by May 10. However, I believe in this curriculum enough that there will be enough support to get this project funded. I also have experience in non-profit and campaign fundraising. Furthermore, what I am requesting is certainly a realistic goal. Because it is an International Conference, IEARN has been able to secure discount rates for the hotel, and I am working with IEARN USA to secure a discounted airfare.

If you are unable to contribute monetarily, you can always circulate this campaign to others who might be interested via e-mail or social media. Also, remember to use the tools that INDIEGOGO has provided. If you have contacts with the media, please let me know, as the media may be a great way to elaborate on my project. Or, you can provide in-kind contributions that can serve as gifts for those who choose to support this project. Any assistance that you can provide would be much appreciated. Any financial contribution that you provide would be much appreciated. You can also contact me and help me organize a fundraiser, especially, if you live in the New York Metro Area.

*All of the artwork that I have displayed has been created by a group of Graffiti artists called the Ex-Vandals. Both of these works were taken on Isham Street in the neighborhood of Inwood in Upper Manhattan.

story:
"I'm not a math person." Sound familiar?

"I'm not a reading person." When's the last time you heard this?

It's unacceptable to be illiterate. Why, then, is it okay to be "bad with numbers?"

At Top Honors, we actively challenge this common misconception about math. Through games, 1-on-1 tutoring, and mentorship led by strong adult role models, we give 6th-8th grade kids the confidence to not only reach fluency in fundamental math skills, but to appreciate the value of math as a critical skill for their everyday successes in the real world.

We believe in rewarding kids for their hard work. Through a unique incentive system that favors positive attitude, effort, and diligence, Top Honors students earn prizes. Some popular prizes include Kindles, Apple products, skateboards, movie tickets, and video games. Our message is simple: work hard and you will be rewarded.

And you know what? It works.

Meet Nobal and his tutor Kandice. 

Nobal worked diligently at Top Honors every week, earning a RipStik skateboard, GameStop certificate, and not one, but two chess sets. Given his hard work, it came as no surprise when he demonstrated proficiency in more than 80% of the Top Honors math curriculum by the end of the year. Kandice, his Saturday tutor, can't wait for Nobal to return as a tutor in a few years when he's old enough.

Nobal was one of nearly 150 kids that volunteers like Kandice tutored on a weekly basis last year, delivering 3,800 hours of free math instruction. 

Help us reach more kids like Nobal. Help us reward their work as they build their self-confidence, honor their commitment to improvement, and declare:

"I'm a math person."

story:
What do these 39 kids, you, and I need?


  • School provides two daily meals to each children. It also provides education: crucial for their future, and ours as a community.
  • The school fees per trimester per child costs 45 dollar.
  • Reaching our goal is paramount!  Share our cause with everyone. 



Our Story

A decade ago a Rwanda girl got kicked out of an orphanage in Uganda. She was sixteen. She was in Uganda because a decade earlier she escaped genocide, fleeing her country. Being in the street was obviously not her first option, but she did choose it.

After being expelled from her residence, she offered to work in the home in exchange for shelter. They accepted. When she found out the orphange wouldn't provide refuge to four HIV positive orphans she reclaimed  her persona non grata status. She found herself in the street - again - taking care of four rejected and sick kids.

Time went by, the stubborn girl grew up, got married, left Uganda. And the four children? What started as an act of compassion and rebelion became an orphanage itself: Mupenzi Children's Home. Home to thirty nine lives. But this story was of love, not of success.



Francisco Germain found a home five months ago: orphanage by name, poverty by definition. Thirty nine children shared two rooms, enjoyed one meal a day, slept in no beds. In his twenty years lifespan he had never faced such misery. Francisco - being human - deemed the conditions inaceptables. When he told me he was bettering the lives of thirty nine kids and that, "Bud, all help is welcomed and needed to rebuild Mupenzi Children's Home," I was glad to join him in Uganda.

Now in our twenty years of existence we've never received so much joy. Francisco's organization - Petits Detalls - rented a better home where the children sleep in beds and eat at a table once a day with their uncles Francisco and Mateo. School provides two more daily meals. And education is a privilege they couldn't afford just a short time ago. Only three months ago, kids woke up at four thirty in the morning to fetch water all morning, and some others couldn't attend due to lack of resources. It's a struggle that continues today.



Enrolling all of our thirty nine kids in school the whole year costs 5,265 dollars. The fees might seem cheap, but education is priceless. And our need to seek funds - even this small amount of help - illustrates the dire situation we live in. If education is a right, providing it is an obligation. Help us fulfill this cause.



The story of this orphanage - or rather: this family - is a tale of survival and we hope of overcoming. And yes, we can take beautiful life lessons from it, meet heroic people like Tira (orphanage's founder). But let's spend a few seconds acknowledging the tragedy of it all. How sad it is to live in a world where large quantities of water costs pennies, yet people still can't afford it. We inhabit a planet were the price of a beer in the States covers the ugandan primary school fees of a child for a whole week. I'm not bringing this up so that every time you lose a penny you fell ashamed, nor am I reprimanding American beer drinkers. I just want you to know how privileged some of us are with our loose change and drunken nights. You drinking one less or six more beers won't condemn a Ugandan child to a life of poverty, and it will not fix the world's problem. So what are we campaigning for? What's the point?

To alter your perception of reality. To expand your horizon. That will change the world. And the children's. Convincing you is easy: Who hasn't had hunger once or twice in their life? You've been cold and thirsty and sad - if only for a minute.

But maybe you can't relate? Because your hunger doesn't mean death, your incompetent president isn't an oppressive dictator and blue and red states aren't the same as a civil war. If that's the case I dare you to get interested: getting to know these thirty nine children will suffice (Francisco and I will gladly share more info by email.) These kids are both a telescope and a microscope. They are Uganda, Africa, the world; they are also America, your state, your family. You.

You, with so much public confidence and private fears. I know. I'm the same: never cutting my hair because I'm afraid it'll never grow back. And you who needs to lose a few pounds - you are your harshest critic. You fit and sexy people who know your didn't get here thanks to your looks: why do you sometimes believe you did? You're not alone. Vanity strikes and unites us all. But - again - I wonder if these kids are not alone. Who can relate? Are you brave enough? They can be so transparent that in the right light you might see yourself reflected. Or even worse - share for a breif moment an ineffable experience. 

When Sharifa - a seven year old whom malnutrition has trapped in an infant's body - saw anyone carrying a stick she would lie down in front of him or her and wait to be beaten. Flora would like to celebrate her birthday (as would many others) but doesn't know the date, and has never met her parents to ask them.


(Sharifa)

What we're feeling right now is compassion. But compassion shouldn't be just a happy/sad feeling. It's an attitude. It's the courage to be vulnerable and the ambition to help where help is needed. It's not

helping African children far far away (but yes, please help us), it's being your neighbors' helping hand, welcoming ears, a shoulder to cry on.

It's giving voice to the voiceless. Because this message isn't ment to be read, but spoken. So share it as I'm sharing it now. 

We will continue to pursue any opportunity that will grant these kids a childhood. We aren't asking for spare change. But change - as only education can provide.

 


More about Petits Details

The name Petits Detalls means Small Details in catalan (language spoken in Catalunya, a region in Spain). Our facebook page - shared here - is also in catalan. So contact me or Francisco to learn more. I still encourage you to visit our page. Images are enough. If they aren't, here's an old article I wrote seeking funds when this commitment wasn't the beautiful big project it is today. Perhaps it shows our humble beginnings. (I hope we will always be humble.) And what we're all about:


No man stands as tall as when he stoops to help a child


A few days from now I’ll head to Entebbe. Though helping children is clearly worth it - and I’ve already participated in a few humanitarian efforts abroad - I still need convincing every once in a while. Is it worth it? Who do I think I am trying to save the world? Only to realize it isn’t about me. But I’m in need of constant reminders. So I’ll write it down, so as not to forget – and in the process, try to inspire you to join us.

You can’t feel bad about not saving the world. If you interrupted your daily routine to contemplate the number of children who live under precarious conditions you’d be crying all day. Thirty-five would suffice. One is already one too many. Nobody asks you to change the world. But you can change someone’s world - even a handful of worlds. Jack Kerouac brilliantly wrote: "…  the people who are crazy enough to think they can change the world are the ones who do." But I see the same craziness inside each and every one of us; some are just sane enough to admit it.

 

Perhaps this is what makes us human after all. Scientists might say that what differentiates us and makes us human is reason, our intelligence, our thirst for knowledge. If that were the case our songs and poems would be about math and scientific inquiry instead of about love and heartache. I think that our humanity stems from the need to live through others. That our craziness in searching for the meaning of our existence – in a reality that doesn’t entertain purpose – in and through others already defines us. It’s the only way we know. Biologists would agree that we need others. They would diverge with regard to why. We are the best adapted to adapt. Survive. So they would call the real tragedy of deafness failing to hear an oncoming threat, while others would lament never enjoying a beautiful melody or the sound of  a parent’s voice. 


This journey towards surmounting the insurmountable has been expressed as many times as there are people on Earth. Grouped by common fundaments such as religion or philosophy. A philosophy that embodies this concept is the Southafrican concept (fairly appropriate for this project) of Ubuntu. It basically consists in recognizing that the only way for me to be human is if you reflect my humanity back at me. Without you, I am not. And if this journey to find ourselves voices itself in theories and superstitions, the way we take each step is in pursuit of happiness. 


It could be that grand projects don’t bring happiness. It could be that happiness dwells in the choreography of the small moments of pleasure we all experience. A few lacking purpose. Others capricious. Like screaming the lyrics of your favorite song at any time of day; dunking trash in a garbage can a few feet away (a few inches are enough); reuniting with a long-lost friend; hugging a complete stranger while celebrating your favorite team’s goal; taking a drag of a cigarette after hours of abstinence; having a love affair; petting a friendly dog; catching in midair something you accidentally dropped; wrapping yourself in the bed sheets on a winter morning; dancing like there’s no tomorrow; seeing a beautiful person for the first time and making a fool of yourself; making a child smile (smiles in general); witnessing a random act of kindness. It’s not random, but it could be a donation to a good cause (after all that is the purpose of this letter). 

These are the little details. I know these instances of happiness are necessary. I’m also aware that one doesn’t find happiness; but stumbles upon it. Maybe these details are the untied shoelace, the bump on the sidewalk or that signpost you don’t see coming. And our human condition of moving towards others is the road. This is why Petits Detalls (Little Details) is special. Quico Germain Borrell started the project. A humble and valuable idea: to focus our help on fulfilling disadvantaged children’s modest dreams. Providing the small details that constitute a childhood – those that so many children don’t have the luxury of having.  That’s what we should band together for. Thanks to the hard work of lots of dedicated and generous people, the orphans of Mupenzi’s orphanage now sleep on mattresses – so they can dream a little more comfortably. Eat at least once a day. Play in an environment free of contaminated water.  Use a decent, hygienic bathroom. They are now beginning to dream of going to school.  For the education, and also for the daily meals the school would provide them. They need your help to reach this dream.


Yes. We want to provide education and daily meals: Knowledge and survival. But it’s not only that. At least it isn’t for me. If it were only that I don’t know if I’d travel there. I’d donate money. Which is already quite a help. If money were unimportant to me I wouldn’t give it to other people. And I wouldn’t ask you to do the same. Petits Detalls – a small wonderful detail in its own right – requires what’s needed to achieve what’s indispensable. To blow candles while your siblings wish you a happy birthday. To have a soccer ball with which to score the winning goal. To listen to stories about far away lands that spark ones imagination. That’s why I’m going. You can go too by donating to the cause. Because today a girl could be attending school and being properly fed - alongside her 34 brothers and sisters. She’ll learn and eat and be happy knowing that she has always mattered. And maybe, through her smile we, too, might find meaning.



Contacts

Francisco Germain (Petits Details founder): quicogb_10@hotmail.com

  • Mateo Pedro Videla ( the guy who wrote this): mateovidela22@gmail.com
story_txt:
What do these 39 kids, you, and I need?







School provides two daily meals to each children. It also provides education: crucial for their future, and ours as a community.
The school fees per trimester per child costs 45 dollar.
Reaching our goal is paramount!  Share our cause with everyone. 




Our Story

A decade ago a Rwanda girl got kicked out of an orphanage in Uganda. She was sixteen. She was in Uganda because a decade earlier she escaped genocide, fleeing her country. Being in the street was obviously not her first option, but she did choose it. 

After being expelled from her residence, she offered to work in the home in exchange for shelter. They accepted. When she found out the orphange wouldn't provide refuge to four HIV positive orphans she reclaimed  her persona non grata status. She found herself in the street - again - taking care of four rejected and sick kids.

Time went by, the stubborn girl grew up, got married, left Uganda. And the four children? What started as an act of compassion and rebelion became an orphanage itself: Mupenzi Children's Home. Home to thirty nine lives. But this story was of love, not of success.








Francisco Germain found a home five months ago: orphanage by name, poverty by definition. Thirty nine children shared two rooms, enjoyed one meal a day, slept in no beds. story:
Short Summary:

Mongolia is known across the world for the amazing dinosaur skeletons found from its Gobi Desert. Skeletons of such well known species as Tarbosaurus, Velociraptor, and Protoceratops are exhibited is museums in New York, Warsaw, Moscow, but as shocking as it might seem, no dinosaur museum exists in the Gobi Desert. As a result most Mongolian kids know little about their dinosaurs and do not have the opportunity to see these stunning specimens. We have acquired a state-of-the art mobile dinosaur museum and have brought it to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia with support of Gerry Ohstrom and Epicurus Fund. Help us prepare the museum for the long trek to the Gobi and get Mongolian kids excited about dinosaurs and science.

Campaign Description:

About the Project

The moveable dinosaur museum is a state-of-the art, walk-in, 37-foot long, handicap accessible vehicle. Inside are exhibits with scientifically accurate dinosaur casts, reconstructions, and videos, many of which feature Mongolian dinosaurs like Velociraptor and Protoceratops. Since 2005 the moveable museum has reached thousands of school kids while traveling throughout the New York City area. Now it is time to move this important moveable museum to the Gobi Desert of Mongolia!

Our Goal

Our campaign goal of $7900 will fund transportation expenses for the moveable dinosaur museum, educational supplies, snacks for students, staff salaries and the transportation, and room and board for the staff members. We estimate that it will cost $1300 in gasoline and tolls round trip to bring the moveable dinosaur museum to the Gobi, and an additional $700 will cover registration and insurance for this vehicle. Educational supplies will cost $350, including the drafting and printing of educational activities, multiple copies of children’s dinosaur books, and the lamination of dinosaur cards for repeated use. The salaries of four staff members (scientist, educator, coordinator, and driver) for a total of 10 days will cost $3400. The staff members room and board for 10 days will cost $1650. The transportation for the staff members will cost $500.

Impact

If you ask Mongolian kids to name one Mongolian dinosaur, most of them struggle. Unlike kids in the US, they just do not have access to books and TV shows on dinosaurs in their native language. We will change all that. Our 10-day program should reach 120 Mongolian school kids: 30 kids from Bulgan town (just a few miles from the famous Flaming Cliffs dinosaur locality), 60 kids from Dalanzadgad (provincial capital of the Flaming Cliffs locality) and 30 kids from Mandalgovi (provincial capital of Dundgovi). We anticipate that once we establish a solid track record of education with the moveable museum in Mongolia with support from this Indiegogo campaign, we will be well positioned to ask for additional funding from several grant agencies to bring the museum to other parts of Mongolia. Eventually, we anticipate that the museum will be able to visit 88 schools, 16 summer camps, and reach 15,000 children every year, and will completely change the landscape of k-12 science education on Mongolia. Our project will build on a growing interest in dinosaurs in Mongolia that follows the repatriation of many stolen dinosaur skeletons. Mongolian and International media has been covering these repatriations, and the return of these dinosaurs has become a major point of Mongolian pride.

Who We Are

The Institute for the Study of Mongolian Dinosaurs (ISMD) was established by Dr. Bolortsetseg Minjin in 2007 as a non-profit, non-government institution. Dr. Bolortsetseg is an accomplished Mongolian paleontologist who has been recognized as an “Emerging Explorer” by National Geographic and explorer of the Wings WorldQuest. She established the ISMD to promote Mongolian paleontology with an emphasis on educational outreach and professional training for aspiring paleontologists.

The ISMD, with the support of the Museum of the Rockies, launched the first dinosaur-focused educational outreach project in Mongolia in 2009. This project reached 32 rural and nomadic kids who live near some of the most famous dinosaur localities in the world. A news story about this project can be found at the following link: http://www.cbc.ca/player/Radio/More+Shows/Dispatches/2009/ID/1470583471/

Since then, the ISMD has continued to conduct educational outreach programs in the Gobi desert and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and since 2012 they expanded their activities to the US so that they could reach Mongolian children living abroad. The ISMD, with the help of several generous donors, has provided financial support to Mongolian students pursuing graduate degrees in paleontology and geology. Most recently the ISMD worked closely with the Mongolian government to bring illegally exported Mongolian dinosaurs back home. Details of these efforts can be found at the following link: http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2013/01/28/130128fa_fact_williams

story:
In Pursuit of Safety & Certainty

My name is Joshua, and I'm an experienced test engineer with a passion for science, and an interest in performance arts that still utilize natural fiber cordage like hemp, jute, and linen.  I'm starting this campaign to raise funding for research materials and technical instruments, in order to study real-world characteristics of natural fiber ropes under dynamic load, with the following in mind:

  • The use of natural fiber ropes for safety-critical rigging hasn't been studied by any industry for decades; most available technical documentation from caving, mountaineering, and nautical use is based on antiquated data, produced from outdated, undocumented, or otherwise questionable experiments.
  • Modern studies of fiber rope for climbing, safety, and industrial use are mostly devoted to specific types of modern cordage that are simply unsuitable for this purpose (like climbing rope).
  •  Practitioners are going to continue to use natural fiber rope in these applications regardless of the availability of synthetic solutions, in order to preserve aesthetically and culturally significant attributes of their art form.
I intend to provide those people with measurable data about the materials they choose to use in the pursuit of their art, and encourage others to continue and supplement these experiments responsibly.

What I'm Asking

In order for this to work, I'm going to need your help in purchasing the following things:

  • One or more load cells rated for safety rigging with a human load; I've selected Rock Exotica's LC1 Enforcer as the ideal candidate.  This will allow me to measure dynamic load unobtrusively and remotely during real-world use.
  • Fully rated hardware to simulate real-world applications of this kind of rigging using materials that I can be confident won't be subject to deformation or failure that may skew test results.
  • Copies of existing standards for the material composition and construction of natural fiber rope, so I can better predict and understand the results of testing based on the inherent properties of the rope.
  • Materials to build a tensile test jig.  A commercially made universal test machine capable of tensile testing is thousands of dollars, and is only useful to baseline the material on a per-sample basis; my goal is to construct a test jig that allows me to recreate the real-world use conditions of multiple strands, and test that entire system holistically, and at a significantly lower cost.
  • Lastly, I'm going to need a lot of rope; I will probably get some direct donations, but in order for the data to be meaningful I will consume at least thirty pieces of thirty-foot rope per test cycle during tensile testing, and that doesn't account for the duplication required to test multiple sources, various diameters, or even different fibers.  The more rope I can get, the more informative these experiments will become.

    The Risks & Rewards

    Going into this, I want everyone to understand that this  is intended to be a long term project; it will take time to raise the money, time to purchase and construct the equipment, and time to carry out the testing itself. 

    • As soon as I hit $800, I will be able to buy the first load cell, and start testing dynamic load.
    • If I hit $1300, I will have enough funds to construct the test jig and purchase the additional rated hardware I need to make it reliable.
    • If I hit $1500 or more, I'll be able to purchase one or more standards from ISO, ASTM, or CI that pertains to the manufacture of natural fiber rope.
    If I exceed my stated goal, my priorities are to purchase at least one additional load cell, supplementary hardware for the test jig, and more rope.  If your donations greatly exceed the goal I've set, I will contact a supplier that manufactures textile pressure sensors, and investigate the possibility of a secondary study of how the forces are applied to the load itself under a variety of conditions (for example, a T-shirt that is made of a pressure sensitive material, and wired up to report pressure per square centimeter via a cable to a laptop).


    How You Can Help

    Your contributions will go directly to purchasing the items I mentioned above, and every contribution helps no matter the size.

    You can also help by spreading the word to other potential contributors, raising awareness of this campaign through Indigogo's own sharing tools, and even donating raw materials (rope) directly.

In Pursuit of Safety & Certainty My name is Joshua, and I'm an experienced test engineer with a passion for science, and an interest in performance arts that still utilize natural fiber cordage like hemp, jute, and linen.  I'm starting this campaign to raise funding for research materials and technical instruments, in order to study real-world characteristics of natural fiber ropes under dynamic load, with the following in mind: 

The use of natural fiber ropes for safety-critical rigging hasn't been studied by any industry for decades; most available technical documentation from caving, mountaineering, and nautical use is based on antiquated data, produced from outdated, undocumented, or otherwise questionable experiments.

Modern studies of fiber rope for climbing, safety, and industrial use are mostly devoted to specific types of modern cordage that are simply unsuitable for this purpose (like climbing rope).  Practitioners are going to continue to use natural fiber rope in these applications regardless of the availability of synthetic solutions, in order to preserve aesthetically and culturally significant attributes of their art form. 
I intend to provide those people with measurable data about the materials they choose to use in the pursuit of their art, and encourage others to continue and supplement these experiments responsibly.

One or more load cells rated for safety rigging with a human load; I've selected Rock Exotica's LC1 Enforcer as the ideal candidate.  This will allow me to measure dynamic load unobtrusively and remotely during real-world use. Fully rated hardware to simulate real-world applications of this kind of rigging using materials that I can be confident won't be subject to deformation or failure that may skew test results.

Copies of existing standards for the material composition and construction of natural fiber rope, so I can better predict and understand the results of testing based on the inherent properties of the rope.
Materials to build a tensile test jig.  A commercially made universal test machine capable of tensile testing is thousands of dollars, and is only useful to baseline the material on a per-sample basis; my goal is to construct a test jig that allows me to recreate the real-world use conditions of multiple strands, and test that entire system holistically, and at a significantly lower cost.

As soon as I hit $800, I will be able to buy the first load cell, and start testing dynamic load.
If I hit $1300, I will have enough funds to construct the test jig and purchase the additional rated hardware I need to make it reliable.
If I hit $1500 or more, I'll be able to purchase one or more standards from ISO, ASTM, or CI that pertains to the manufacture of natural fiber rope.

If I exceed my stated goal, my priorities are to purchase at least one additional load cell, supplementary hardware for the test jig, and more rope.  If your donations greatly exceed the goal I've set, I will contact a supplier that manufactures textile pressure sensors, and investigate the possibility of a secondary study of how the forces are applied to the load itself under a variety of conditions (for example, a T-shirt that is made of a pressure sensitive material, and wired up to report pressure per square centimeter via a cable to a laptop).


  How You Can Help Your contributions will go directly to purchasing the items I mentioned above, and every contribution helps no matter the size.
You can also help by spreading the word to other potential contributors, raising awareness of this campaign through Indigogo's own sharing tools, and even donating raw materials (rope) directly.

story:
"Soft butt, what moon breaks wind through yonder window?"

How many of you had to study Shakespeare in high school?

How many of you enjoyed it?

Liars.

Seriously, due to budget cuts and test curriculum most students find the study of Shakespeare to be boring at best, confusing at worst and all around a waste of time. Very few teachers have the time or training to bring Shakespeare off the page and onto the stage - into the realm of theatre.

We believe Shakespeare's plays are meant to be performed on the stage, not just read off the page.

Our goal is to help teachers and communities bring Shakespeare alive in the classroom and on the stage by providing an affordable professional quality resource to make theatre arts programming and instruction available to schools as well as other under-served populations.


Who Are We?

Passado Action Theatre is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization which aims to keep the arts alive in schools and communities where lack of funding has reduced student exposure to live theatre.  Artistic directors Dennis McLaughlin and Ri Walton toured throughout New England performing and teaching Shakespeare and performance techniques in hundreds of schools for nearly 20 years. Since moving to California in 2001  they have had great success working with teachers to bring action theatre techniques to productions of A Midsummer Night's Dream, Macbeth, Romeo and Juliet, and more. In the last 8 years, the company has grown to 6 professional actors with over 50 combined years of experience in the entertainment and educational industries. 

What is Shakespeare Unplugged ?

This show features dramatic and comedic Shakespearean scenes involving physical action and unarmed or weapons combat, from the  hysterical slapstick in A Midsummer's Night Dream, to Macbeth‘s medieval sword-and-shield style and Romeo and Juliet‘s renaissance rapier and dagger technique. Shows can be tailored to current English/Shakespeare/History curricula, and are designed to jump-start an exploration into the nearly infinite possibilities of physical interpretation of Shakespeare.

How Can You Help?

We are asking for your financial support for a  west coast version of "Shakespeare Unplugged".  This program will give teachers, directors, and community leaders access to affordable, professional quality resources, including full scale performances, assemblies, workshops and/or educational support.



    What We Need & What You Get

    Our fundraising goal is $35,000, which includes:

    • Dedicated indoor rehearsal space
    • Actor compensation
    • Safety equipment, props and costumes
    • Workshop materials for student use
    • Grant and funding outreach
    • Development of curriculum materials based on state and national standards
    • PR materials to connect with teachers, schools, and communities

    Benefits:

    • That warm glow in knowing you've helped us develop "Shakespeare Unplugged" and get the program out to the schools and communities in southern California
    • Achieve immortality in Passado Action Theatre's Hall of Donors
    • Email updates, shout-outs, certificates, Passado Action Theatre calendars and  special thank you DVD's of our greatest moments (including hilarious bloopers!)
    • Access to workshops, classes and VIP performances
    • More to come...keep an eye on our perks section!

      The Impact

      You will be helping Passado Action Theatre keep the performing arts alive in schools and communities at a time when funding and support for the arts is being constantly cut or eliminated altogether.  Research shows that involvement in the performing arts keeps students in schools, increases their chances of going on to college, and improves their overall success in adult careers.

      You will also be supporting our mission to address the very real concern that our society is becoming ever more numb to the levels of violence in our media culture. We're not  talking about censorship - rather the development  of an informed and critical awareness  of how the choices we make in creating performances and what we choose to watch can make a difference.  If we change one person's perception, we have started to change the world.

      The creators of Passado Action Theatre, Dennis McLaughlin and Ri Walton have considerable experience with this. Between 1980 and 2000, their work in the schools with the New Hampshire Theatre Project (an organization McLaughlin co-founded) impacted thousands of students on the East coast- teaching performance skills, engendering a respect and appreciation for live theatre and inspiring many students to embark on successful careers in the entertainment industry. They have been doing the same here in California since 2001.

        Risks & Challenges

        Let's be honest.  The biggest challenge to this project is going to be money.  Schools and under-served communities are always scrambling for one more dollar to make ends meet. In times of tight budgets,  the arts are often relegated to the bottom of the list of funding priorities. All too often the arts are treated as non-necessities or even more depressing; frills.

        Passado Action Theatre has a strategy that has been proven to work for over 28 years. We start with the mandate to keep our services affordable. We network with schools and communities to help them secure funding for our programs.  And we continually work to attract public and private support -

        Hey! That's you!

        Other Ways You Can Help

        • Boost the signal! Like us on Facebook, then share our posts. Talk about us. Tell your families and friends!
        • Use Indigogo share tools!
        • In-kind Donations - Donations of goods (i.e. computer, printer, paper... etc...) and services (business/restaurant discounts etc...) are invaluable in helping Passado accomplish its mission statement. Check out the wish list on Passado's website for more information.
        • Volunteer - You can contribute in this cause by volunteering at Passado events.

        Once more unto the breach, dear friends!
